Article.ArticleTitle: Temporal dynamics of urban air pollutants and their correlation with associated meteorological parameters: an investigation in northern Indian cities.

AbstractText: This study delves into the intricate dynamics of air pollution in the rapidly expanding northern regions of India, examining the intertwined influences of agricultural burning, industrialization, and meteorological conditions. Through comprehensive analysis of key pollutants (PM<sub>2.5</sub>, PM<sub>10</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, SO<sub>2</sub>, CO, O<sub>3</sub>) across ten monitoring stations in Uttar Pradesh, Haryana, Delhi, and Punjab, a consistent pattern of high pollution levels emerges, particularly notable in Delhi. Varanasi leads in SO<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> concentrations, while Moradabad stands out for CO levels, and Jalandhar for SO<sub>2</sub> concentrations. The study further elucidates the regional distribution of pollutants, with Punjab receiving significant contributions from SW, SE, and NE directions, while Haryana and Delhi predominantly face air masses from SE and NE directions. Uttar Pradesh's pollution sources are primarily local, with additional inputs from various directions. Moreover, significant negative correlations (p < 0.05) between PM<sub>10</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, SO<sub>2</sub>, O<sub>3</sub>, and relative humidity (RH) underscore the pivotal role of meteorological factors in shaping pollutant levels. Strong positive correlations between PM<sub>2.5</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> (0.71 to 0.93) suggest shared emission sources or similar atmospheric conditions in several cities. This comprehensive understanding highlights the urgent need for targeted mitigation strategies to address the multifaceted drivers of air pollution, ensuring the protection of public health and environmental sustainability across the region.
